metadata.title: Engineered nano-zirconium oxide-crosslinked-nanolayer of carboxymethyl cellulose for speciation and adsorptive removal of Cr(III) and Cr(VI)

sections.text:
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
A novel nanosorbent is designed via crosslinking of nanolayer
carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) onto the surface of nano-zirconium oxide (Nano-ZrO2) using glutaraldehyde for the formation of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC. The nanosorbents were characterized using TGA, SEM, HR-TEM, FT-IR and surface area analysis. The particle size of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC was 22-39 nm. The potential implementation of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent for selective speciation and extraction of chromium ions from real water samples and aqueous solutions was explored and compared versus Nano-ZrO2 sorbent using the batch technique in presence of various values of pH, time, mass of sorbent, concentration and competing ions. The maximum metal capacity values of chromium (VI) by Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC and Nano-ZrO2 were identified as 680 and 120 µmol g -1 , respectively in pH 1.0-2.0, while the identified maximum values of chromium (III) were 1120 and 500 µmol g -1 , respectively in pH 7.0. Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC and Nano-ZrO2 sorbents were further successfully applied for speciation of Cr(VI) and Cr(III) as well as adsorptive removal from tap water, sea water and industrial wastewater samples adjusted to pH 7.0 and 2.0, respectively. The identified percentage values of chromium species by the multistage microcolumn technique confirmed the superiority of ZrO2-glu-CMC versus Nano-ZrO2 based on the determined recovery range 97.9-100.0% and 89.6-100.0%, respectively. Keywords: Zirconium oxide, Carboxymethyl cellulose, Glutaraldehyde, Chromium speciation, Adsorption.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Among the various metals, chromium is a well-known toxic heavy metal that
is considered as a significant pollutant in drinking water due to commonly use in various industrial activities. Generally, chromium is encountered in the environment as hexavalent and trivalent ions. These two oxidation states have different biological, environmental and chemical properties. Chromium (VI) is highly toxic and soluble and is known as the reason for human diseases such as damage to liver, skin and kidney, dermatitis, hepatic and renal tubular necrosis. On the other hand, Cr(III) is less harmful, relatively insoluble, immobile and playing an important role in the protein metabolism, lipid and glucose [1-4]. Generally, the removal of chromium is focused on Cr(VI) more than Cr(III) due to it has more toxic effect. Nowadays, there are a number of different methods for heavy metal extraction from water, including but not limited to electrochemical technologies, chemical precipitation, membrane filtration, ion exchange and adsorption [5-9]. The adsorption technique is mainly based on the attachment of soluble species to the surface of solid materials. The advantages of this process are directly related to its low cost, ease of operation, high and selectivity for specific metals. Therefore, the adsorption technique is now considered as one of the highly demanded approaches for removal of heavy metal from seawater, wastewater and tap water [10-11].
Water treatment by adsorption techniques was recently reported using
different types of nano-sorbents and these materials may include several important types of carbonaceous structures such as carbon nano-particles, carbon nano-sheets and carbon nano-tubes [12]. However, modified or unmodified inorganic nano-particles are presented by different examples such as metallic silver and gold [13, 14], metal oxide nano-particles including iron oxide [15], aluminum oxide [16], titanium oxide [17] and silicon oxide [18]. Other examples of nano-metal oxide materials may also include nano-manganese oxides (NMnOs) which are characterized to exhibit more adsorptive performance compared to the bulk counterpart due to its high specific surface area and

polymorphic structure and thus were used for extraction of toxic heavy metal ions such as mercury and cadmium. However, the major disadvantage of these materials is their possible aggregation in aqueous solutions [19, 20]. ZnO and MgO nanoparticles were also considered as excellent sorbents for extraction of copper (II) from wastewater [21]. Nano-Al2O3 with certain functional donor groups such as phosphorus, sulfur, nitrogen and oxygen were used to obtain better sorption efficiency for heavy metals as previously reported [22]. NanoTiO2 was identified to exhibite 15.3 and 7.9 mg g -1 at pH 9.0 as the capacity values of zinc (II) and cadmium (II), respectively and some common anions as well as cations were found to show no significant influence toward heavy metals on the adsorption technique [23].
ZrO2 is well characterized by its low solubility, high thermal stability,
amphoteric character and good resistance to oxidant agents. It is easier and cheaper to synthesis compared to other organic resins and has been known to have a remarkable selectivity to certain ions [24, 25]. The production processes of ZrO2 are generally based on wet chemical methods such as coprecipitation, cryochemical, sol-gel methods, hydrolysis of metal alcoholates and hydrothermal synthesis [26]. In addition, ZrO2 as an adsorbent was reported by its strong affinity to negatively charged moieties such as antimony (V) [27], phosphate ion [28] and arsenic [29]. In addition, hydrous zirconium oxide was used for extraction of Cr(VI) from aqueous solution as previously reported [30]. Zirconium oxide ethylenediamine adipate (ZEDA) was synthesized using sol–gel technique for the removal of chromium (IV) and arsenic (III) [31]. Zr(IV) loaded ligand exchange adsorbent by adsorption process was reported for removal of arsenic (V) from water [32].
Polymeric materials are generally considered as suitable sorbents because
they afford large surface area and production at low cost with repeatability and precision [33]. Polymers such as sodium carboxymethyl cellulose, hydroxypropylmethyl cellulose, hydroxyethyl cellulose, polyvinylpyrrolidone, pectin, hydroxypropyl cellulose, carboxymethyl starch and carrageenan as well as

other polysaccharide derivatives were identified to have a wide range of applications such as extraction of heavy metals from pharmaceutical industry and industrial wastewater [34]. However, there are several disadvantages when using polysaccharides in water treatment including the strong dependence on the degree of N-acetylation, molecular weight, solution properties, crystallinity as well as swelling and diffusion properties. These are generally used to outline the application limitations of these materials in an industrial-scale as previously reported [35]. CMC is an anionic water soluble natural polymer derivative, which is widely used in oil exploration, detergents and in the food, textile industries and paper because of its viscosity-increasing properties and nontoxicity [36]. In addition, CMC is a biodegradable, naturally polymer present with some functional groups on the surface [33]. Several reports have also indicated the cellulose-based material can remove heavy metals including different molecular structures. Sodium CMC was used in combination with activated carbon (AC) and polyvinylalcohol (PVA) under conditions such as pH 5.0, treatment time (85 min), adsorbent loading (0.1 g) and metal concentration (0.1 g L −1 ) to remove copper (II) and chromium (VI) [33]. CMC beads were used as a control system for immobilized form of fungus to remove Cr(VI) from aqueous solutions and the maximum metal capacities were identified as 32.2 and 18.9 mg g -1 for the immobilized and free fungus, respectively [37]. Novel adsorbent was synthized by using acrylic acid and carboxymethyl cellulose for removal of dyes and the removal capacity reached to 79.6%, 84.2% and 99.9% for disperse blue 2BLN, methyl orange and malachite green chloride, respectively [38]. Several cellulosebased adsorbents were prepared by various methods and the modified adsorbents were applied for removal of various pollutants (organics, radionuclides, inorganic anions, metals and dyes) from water and wastewater [39].
In this study, nanolayers of carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) were
immobilized via crosslinking glutaraldehyde reagent on the surface of Nano-ZrO2 for the formation of a novel Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent. This was identified by the FT-IR, TGA, SEM, BET-surface area and HR-TEM. The various controlling

The main objective of this study is also directed to compare the performance and potential applications of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC and Nano-ZrO2 sorbent in water treatment of chromium species.

The concentration of metal ions, Cr(III) and Cr(VI) were measured by an atomic absorption spectrophotometer, model 2380. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) and thermoanalytical curves of Nano-ZrO2 and NanoZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents were acquired using a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 Thermobalance. sections.heading: 3.1 Characterization
sections.text:
In this work, Nano-ZrO2 and modified Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents were
compared using SEM, TGA, TEM, BET and FT-IR analysis. The SEM images of Nano-ZrO2 and Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents are shown in Figure 1. The SEMimage of Nano-ZrO2 is characterized by the distribution of this material as spherical particles with different sizes in the range of 34-57 nm. On the other hand, the SEM image of the newly designed and synthesized Nano-ZrO2-gluCMC material was found to be completely different from that of Nano-ZrO2 as represented in Figure 1 due to surface loading and coating with nanolayer of CMC. However, the SEM-image of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent was also characterized by the distribution of this material as spherical particles with different sizes in the range of 22-39 nm. This confirms the breakage of possible aggregates in Nano-ZrO2 sorbent and surface loading of nanolayers of glu-CMC material. Therefore, the SEM results can be used to refer to the different chemical structure and surface morphology of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC compared to NanoZrO2. In addition, the HR-TEM images of Nano-ZrO2 and Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents are shown in Figures 2A and 2B, respectively. The particles of NanoZrO2 are clearly shown by nanolayers or nanosheets coverage of CMC to produce the synthesized Nano-ZrO2-Glu-CMC.
The FT-IR spectroscopic analysis of Nano-ZrO2 and modified Nano-ZrO2
sorbents were also studied to compare the different functional groups as shown in Figure 3. The FT-IR spectrum of Nano-ZrO2 sorbent is characterized by the presence of only two characteristic peaks at 745.7 and 524.3 cm -1 . These peaks are related to Zr-O bond [40]. Similarly, the FT-IR spectrum of Nano-ZrO2-glu-

CMC sorbent indicates the presence of carboxyl, methyl and hydroxyl functional groups at 1715.8, 1122.1 and 1062.6 cm -1 , respectively. The peak at 2926.5 cm -1 is mainly due to the aliphatic C-H bond. The identified broad peak at 3430.7 cm -1 is mainly related to the stretching frequency of hydroxyl group (-OH) [40]. The weakness and shifting of peak intensity of Nano-ZrO2 to 746.7 and 522.4 cm -1 , respectively are produced as a result of coating Nano-ZrO2 with CMC. On the other hand, the FT-IR spectra of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC-loaded-Cr(III) and NanoZrO2-glu-CMC-loaded-Cr(VI) have been also studied and listed in the supplementary materials as S1 and S2, respectively. It is evident that several new and intense peaks were characterized in the range 516-743 cm -1 due to the possible binding of either Cr(III) or Cr(VI) to the loaded functional donor atoms on the surface of newly synthesized Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC nanosorbent.
The TGA-thermogram of Nano-ZrO2 sorbent is shown in Figure 4a and
refers to undetected mass loss of this sorbent. This indicates that Nano-ZrO2 is more thermally stable than Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC. Thus, the surface immobilization of CMC on Nano-ZrO2 for the formation of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent was found to produce a less stable sorbent in the studied heating temperature range 50-600 o C. Figure 4b represents the TGA-thermogram of Nano-ZrO2-Glu-CMC sorbent and clearly refers to the existence of four successive thermal degradation steps at 23.45-134.83 O C, 134.83-216.46 O C, 216.46-313.92 °C and 313.92-599.75 °C. As previously mentioned, the first thermal decomposition step (23.45-134.83 O C) is mainly related to the desorption of surface water molecules with a percentage loss of (10.294%). However, the second degradation step (134.83-216.46 O C) is suggested to produce by the simple and direct thermal degradation and loss of the loaded organic molecules (9.214%). The third and four steps are mainly due to the direct decomposition of the surface loaded organic compound at degradation temperature ranges of 216.46-313.92 °C and 313.92-599.75 °C with percentage loss values of 10.747% and 5.051%, respectively.

The surface area of Nano-ZrO2 sorbent was also determined and
characterized by using four different methods, BJH cumulative desorption surface area method, DH cumulative desorption surface area method, t-process of external surface area and DFT cumulative surface area. The output data for these methods are listed in Table 1. The pore volume and pore size values of NanoZrO2 sorbent were determined and compiled also in Table 1. The collected data prove a large surface area of the synthesized Nano-ZrO2 sorbent and this can enhance the adsorption efficiency for heavy metals. The identified surface area of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent by the multipoint BET was found 24.13 m 2 /g which is greater than that of Nano-ZrO2 sorbent (9.983 m 2 /g) as listed in Table 1. This high surface area value can be used to account for the possibility of high adsorption efficiency toward heavy metals. In addition, this may be also used to give a good evidence for the successful coating process of carboxymethyl cellulose on the surface of Nano-ZrO2. In addition, the surface area of NanoZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent was also determined by the same fourth methods as mentioned above. The identified data of pore volume and pore size of NanoZrO2 and are Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC also listed in Table 1 for comparison.

sections.heading: 3.2 Sorption studies of chromium
sections.text:
The sorption characteristics of chromium ions by newly designed and
functionalized Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC were compared versus Nano-ZrO2 in order to identify the µmol g -1 metal capacity values using the batch equilibrium technique under the influence of pH, contact time, mass of sorbent, initial metal ion concentration and interfering ions according to the following procedures.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Influence of pH on the chromium capacity values by Nano-ZrO2-glu-

CMC and Nano-ZrO2 in presence of various initial pH values (1.0-7.0) of contact solutions are listed in Table 2 and the possible binding of metal ions to the

surface of Nano-ZrO2 and modified Nano-ZrO2 sorbents are shown in Schemes 2 and 3. In addition, there is a good possibility of metal binding between two adjacent carboxylate groups from two different CMC chains as previously reported [41].
Chromium exists in water in a number of oxidation states as previously
reported [42]. The most common forms of chromium ions are Cr(III) and Cr(VI). The distribution of these ions in water and aqueous solutions depends mainly on the pH value of their solutions. Cr(VI) may be present in aqueous solutions as chromate, dichromate, hydrogen chromate, chromic acid, and hydrogen dichromate. On the other hand, Cr(III) may exist in aqueous solution as hydroxo species and hydroxylated chromium complex in the form of Cr(OH)2 + , Cr(OH)3, Cr(OH)4 − , Cr2(OH)4 2+ , and Cr3(OH)5 + . It is well known that Cr(OH)3(s) and Cr(OH)4 − are most likely to exist in alkaline medium and this minimizes the availability of Cr(III) species to bind with the negatively charged sites which exist on the surface of sorbents. Therefore, the present study is not reporting the sorption process in alkaline medium. It is evident from the listed data that sorption processes of chromium ions were found to exhibit a significant dependence on the pH of solution. The metal capacity values of chromium (III) by Nano-ZrO2 and modfied Nao-ZrO2 sorbents were identified to increase as the pH increase, since the functional groups present on the surface (hydroxyl) are expected to be deprotonated upon increasing the pH of contact solution. This condition leads to more expected negatively charged active sites that are capable of binding with the cationic Cr(III) hydroxyl species such as Cr(OH) 2+ and Cr(OH)2 + [43]. However, at lower pH (< 3.0), the amount of removed Cr(III) is low owing to the competition between the free Cr(III) and H + ions toward the active sites on the sorbent. The maximum sorption capacity value of chromium (III) by Nano-ZrO2 was identified as 500 µmol g -1 in pH 7.0 and the corresponding value of chromium (III) by Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC was detected as 1120 µmol g -1 at pH 7.0. This behavior refers to the contribution of loaded CMC

on the surface of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent if compared to the data of NanoZrO2 as compiled in Table 2.
The results of metal capacities of Cr(VI) are also shown in Table 2. The
calculated metal capacity values of chromium (VI) by Nano-ZrO2 and modified Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents were found to decrease upon increasing the initial pH value of contact solution. In addition, such observation of the metal capacity increase in low pH values is mainly attributed to the overall surface functional groups which are protonated and can be easily bind with the negatively charged HCrO4 − and Cr2O7 2− species. In this case, the positively charged sites increased by decreasing pH value of contact solution [44]. Accordingly, as the pH of the system increases, the number of positively charged sites decreases so that the metal capacity of the negatively charged chromium (VI) species decreased. Moreover, at lower pH (< 2.0), there is a possibility of formation of more polymerized chromium oxide species such as Cr3O10 2− and Cr4O13 2- which results in the decrease in chromium (VI) metal capacity by various sorbents [45].
The comparison of the sorption capacity values of chromium (VI) using
Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent in presence of the examined range of pH were found higher than those detected by Nano-ZrO2 sorbent. These were identified to increase from 120 using Nano-ZrO2 to 680 µmol g -1 using Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent at pH 2.0 and to increase from 40 to 360 µmol g -1 in pH 7.0, respectively. These values confirm that the immobilization of CMC nanolayers on the surface of Nano-ZrO2 which is considered as the main reason for such high contribution as given in Table 2.

Various shaking time values (1, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 40, 50 and 60 min) were taken and investigated using 25±1 mg of sorbent in presence of the optimum pH 2.0 and 7.0 for Cr(VI) and Cr(III), respectively. The results of this study are graphed in Figure 5.
The sorption interaction processes of Cr(III) and Cr(VI) ions with Nano-
ZrO2 and Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents were identified to follow two successive steps. The first step refers to the rapid and efficient increase in the removal process of Cr(III) and Cr(VI) ions due to the abundant availability of active binding sites on the surface of both Nano-ZrO2 and Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents. With the gradual increase in the metal sorption capacity due to gradual occupancy of the surface active sites, the sorption processes turn to be less efficient. The second step in this sorption mechanism is mainly related to the equilibrium which is focused on the complete surface saturation (100%) of NanoZrO2 and Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents with either Cr(III) or Cr(VI) species [46]. On the other hand, modification of the Nano-ZrO2 sorbent via immobilization of CMC was found to improve and enhance the sorption efficiency.
It was also found that the equilibrium conditions for the interaction and
binding processes of Cr(III) with Nano-ZrO2 and Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents were found to reach to 30.0 min of contact time with the maximum metal sorption capacity values as 500 and 1200 µmol g -1 , respectively. Similarly, Cr(VI) sorption by Nano-ZrO2 and Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbents was found to reach to the equilibrium condition at 30.0 min of contact time due to complete saturation and the maximum capacities correspond to 120 and 720 µmol g -1 , respectively.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this work, the surface of zirconium oxide nanoparticles, Nano-ZrO2, was
successfully crosslinked via a green chemical process without using organic solvents. Pure glutaraldehyde was implemented as an efficient crosslinking reagent to immobilize nanolayers of carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) derivative on the surface of ZrO2 nanoparticles to produce a novel Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent. The identified surface area of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent was found 24.13 m 2 /g which is greater than that of Nano-ZrO2 sorbent (9.983 m 2 /g) The sorption characteristics of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC were compared with Nano-ZrO2 and found more superior with respect to the metal capacity values as well as the recovery of chromium species from real water samples. The value of pH 7.0 was identified as the optimum buffering condition for removal of Cr(III) from aqueous solution due possible complex formation mechanism. On the other hand, the range of pH 1.0-2.0 was confirmed to enforce efficient sorption of Cr(VI) from aqueous solution due to the presence of protonated functional groups which are easily bound with the negatively charged HCrO4 − and Cr2O7 2− species. This variation was utilized for selective speciation and adsorptive removal of low concentration levels of chromium species from real water samples such as tap water, industrial wastewater and sea water samples by using the microcolumn technique. The results confirmed percentage recovery values of Cr(III) and Cr(VI) in the ranges 91.9 -100.0 % and 89.6 - 100.0%, respectively.

metadata.abstractText: A novel nanosorbent is designed via crosslinking of nanolayer carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) onto the surface of nano-zirconium oxide (Nano-ZrO2) using glutaraldehyde for the formation of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC. The nanosorbents were characterized using TGA, SEM, HR-TEM, FT-IR and surface area analysis. The particle size of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC was 22-39 nm. The potential implementation of Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC sorbent for selective speciation and extraction of chromium ions from real water samples and aqueous solutions was explored and compared versus Nano-ZrO2 sorbent using the batch technique in presence of various values of pH, time, mass of sorbent, concentration and competing ions. The maximum metal capacity values of chromium (VI) by Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC and Nano-ZrO2 were identified as 680 and 120 μmol g -1 , respectively in pH 1.0-2.0, while the identified maximum values of chromium (III) were 1120 and 500 μmol g -1 , respectively in pH 7.0. Nano-ZrO2-glu-CMC and Nano-ZrO2 sorbents were further successfully applied for speciation of Cr(VI) and Cr(III) as well as adsorptive removal from tap water, sea water and industrial wastewater samples adjusted to pH 7.0 and 2.0, respectively. The identified percentage values of chromium species by the multistage microcolumn technique confirmed the superiority of ZrO2-glu-CMC versus Nano-ZrO2 based on the determined recovery range 97.9-100.0% and 89.6-100.0%, respectively.
